Name: Single Estate Peaberry Medium Roast
Review: ong>A pure, lyric, light-roasted breakfast coffee, gently exotic.

Name: Kenya Mamuto
Review: ong>A stunning coffee, both grand and balanced.

Name: Guatemala El Injerto
Review: ong>Lovers of delicate elegance in beverages.

Name: Colombia Villa Flor
Review: ong>Lovers of big, forceful white table wines.

Name: Organic Fair-Trade Ethiopia Yirgacheffe
Review: ong>For those who know coffee, an archetypally floral-toned Yirgacheffe. For those who don't, buy it if you enjoy Rieslings and intense but delicate floral-toned whites. Impeccable social and environmental credentials.
Coffee Origin: Yirgacheffe growing region, Sidamo Province, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Vermont Country Blend
Review: ong>A coffee with unsentimental but pleasing chocolate notes stiffened by a gentle pungency. A fine breakfast coffee for those who avoid brightly acidy cups.

Name: Mocha Java Light Roast
Review: ong>Those who enjoy Highland whiskies that introduce a touch of smoke in an otherwise sweet and citrusy profile. Or those to whom that description sounds attractive.
Coffee Origin: Harrar region of eastern Ethiopia; east Java, Indonesia.

Name: Our Blend
Review: ong>Relaxed breakfast cuppers who want their coffee to murmur melodically rather than carry on with acidy operatics.

Name: Organic Fair-Trade House Blend
Review: ong>A balanced, quietly low-toned medium-dark roast with sound social and environmental credentials.

Name: Organic Fair-Trade Espresso Blend
Review: ong>Those who enjoy tequilas, retsina, any beverage with a savory/salty bite complicating a more familiar (in this case dark, roasty chocolate) flavor complex.

Name: Dark Magic Blend
Review: ong>Those who enjoy rough, rugged dark roasts with some complicating nuance and good sweetness.

Name: Double Black Diamond Dark Roast (K-Cup)
Review: ong>Keurig owners who enjoy a smooth, bittersweet, quietly complex dark-roasted cup.

Name: Pacific Coast Dark Roast
Review: ong>A Pacific Coast Dark Roast for subtle palates: Pungent but quiet, complex.

Name: Breakfast Blend
Review: ong>A versatile breakfast cup both robustly acidy and elegantly sweet.

Name: Kenya AB Decaf
Review: ong>Essentially a pleasantly balanced dark roast with nice mouthfeel. Little Kenya character that I could detect.

Name: Pitalito Estates Colombian Supremo Decaffeinated
Review: ong>Those who avoid caffeine but still enjoy a simple, strong-gestured traditional breakfast cup.

Name: Peru La Florida Decaf Fair-Trade
Review: ong>A classic Peru for caffeine-avoiders: delicate, simple, sweetly pleasing.

Name: Decaf Sumatra
Review: ong>Caffeine-avoiding lovers of classic earth-toned Sumatras.

Name: Decaffeinated Costa Rica
Review: ong>A classic medium-roasted Costa Rica breakfast cup carrying just a little decaf baggage.

Name: Decaf Harfusa Ethiopia Yirgacheffe
Review: ong>An exotic and engaging breakfast-style cup for caffeine-avoiders. Should maintain character nicely under the impact of modest quantities of whitener.
Coffee Origin: Yirgacheffe growing region, Sidamo Province, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Mexican Altura Decaf Fair-Trade Organic
Review: ong>Those who don't need caffeine boost to hug trees. About as impeccably environmentally and socially progressive as a coffee can get, this sample also displays the elegant, gentle cup character typical of many of the best Mexico coffees, nicely rounded by the roast.

Name: Sumatra Lake Tawar Decaf
Review: ong>Those caffeine-avoiders looking for an opulently elegant version of the traditional earthy, malty Sumatra.
Coffee Origin: Lake Tawar basin, Aceh Province, northern Sumatra, Indonesia

Name: Mexico La Union Medium Roast
Review: ong>Those interested in a classic Mexico profile, at least one kind of classic Mexico profile: not particularly assertive nor complex, but sweet, balanced, with low-acid citrus, dark chocolate, rose-toned flowers - quiet and pure.

Name: Five Sisters Premium Blend, Fair-Trade Organic
Review: ong>Those who want to support a impressively globe-spanning progressive social enterprise by drinking a simple, robust blend.

Name: Sumatra Danau Toba
Review: ong>Lovers of the sensory paradox found in Port wines and other fruitily sweet yet pungently deep beverages.
Coffee Origin: Lake Toba region, North Sumatra Province, Sumatra, Indonesia

Name: Single Origin Medium Roast
Review: ong>A quiet, gently exotic breakfast cup.

Name: Colombia Huila Monserrate Excelso
Review: ong>Floral top notes float over a succession of rougher, more pungent sensations, making this a coffee for those who enjoy paradox and contradiction.

Name: Colombia Maragogipe Rainforest Alliance
Review: ong>Those who value delicacy in a breakfast coffee and/or those in pursuit of a novelty coffee with good cup character. Avoid dampening its delicacy with whitener or sweetener.

Name: Colombia Estrella del Sur
Review: ong>Those who prefer gentleness and simplicity to acidy excitement.

Name: Colombian Breakfast Blend
Review: ong>The dominant baker's chocolate and walnut notes make this a strong-presenced cup despite its delicacy, with enough grace to be enjoyed black and enough substance to handle whitener.

Name: Colombia Humbenito Gonzales
Review: ong>Those who prefer balance to challenge in breakfast coffees.

Name: Colombia La Golondrina Odair Achipiz Cauca
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a quiet but complex coffee with great versatility, which means it should be able to handle at least a little whitener or sweetener and drink well after dinner.
Coffee Origin: Valle de Cauca Department, western Colombia

Name: Colombia Tres Santos Micro-Lot El Portal
Review: ong>A classic, complete Latin-American high-grown breakfast cup.
Coffee Origin: Valle de Cauca Department, western Colombia

Name: Reserva del Patron Colombia Narino
Review: ong>The crisply sweet, exhilarating dry berry notes are reminiscent of great Kenya coffees. The berryish fruit takes on a distinctly chocolaty cast in milk.

Name: Colombia Micro-Lot Huila La Argentina
Review: ong>Great intensity, presence and classic simplicity (in Art 101 terms, more Doric than Ionic).

Name: Colombia Micro-Lot Humberto Gonzales
Review: ong>A classic breakfast cup, grandly sweet but dry, with a coffee fruit too true for analogies.

Name: Tres Santos Micro-Lot La Dorada Cauca
Review: ong>An elegant and complete coffee expression, accessible but rewarding.
Coffee Origin: Valle de Cauca Department, western Colombia

Name: Colombia Tolima Jairo Guiterrez Micro-Lot 07
Review: ong>A coffee so intensely and completely classic that it becomes, essentially, something new and distinctive.

Name: Organic Colombia
Review: ong>A refined and refreshing coffee with great natural sweetness and balance. Avoid adding anything to it.
Coffee Origin: Fondo Paez Cooperative, Valle de Cauca Department, western Colombia.

Name: Costa Rica Dark Roast
Review: ong>A gentle dark-roasted coffee for those who prefer charm to challenge. Go easy on sweetener or whitener.

Name: Costa Rica Breakfast Blend
Review: ong>At this roast level a coffee as fresh and pure as morning on the farm.

Name: Sumatra Mandheling, South Italian Espresso Roast
Review: ong>An espresso that subtly but powerfully expresses the pungently complex, earth-and-chocolate character of its Sumatra origin.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, North Sumatra Province, Indonesia.

Name: Nectar
Review: ong>A deeply original coffee, allusive but unique.

Name: Rwandan French Roast
Review: ong>A bargain-priced ultra-dark "French" roast that situates somewhere between the lifeless, flat, robusta-heavy French roasts in supermarket cans and the aromatically limited/nuance-challenged but ruggedly pungent versions from good specialty roasters. This one is rugged but also a touch rubbery.

Name: 100% Arabica
Review: ong>A decent, low-key, agreeable coffee at a startlingly low price.

Name: 100% Colombia Dark Roast
Review: ong>A lushly sweet, low-acid coffee with the character of mildly fermented bananas at a bargain price. You know who you are.

Name: Organic Sumatra Fair-Trade, Medium Dark Roast
Review: ong>Balanced and accessible with little of the earthy, pungent character associated with Sumatras. A Sumatra-lite with excellent social and environmental credentials.

Name: Premium Ground Coffee Fair Trade Certified
Review: ong>An everybody-wins coffee, with growers benefiting from the minimum Fair-Trade price and penny-conscious consumers from a decent if simple coffee at an extremely low retail price.

Name: Classic Blend
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a very quiet morning cup. The sweet wood notes are soft and agreeable rather than dull and board-like.

Name: Rainforest Alliance Breakfast Blend
Review: ong>A quietly pleasing coffee with bonus environmental credentials for those who prefer a gentle, low-acid, cocoa-toned breakfast cup.

Name: 100% Tanzanian
Review: ong>A plausible Kenya-lite for those bargain-hunters who enjoy the pungent dry berry character of good Kenyas but find their often intense acidity too overbearing.

Name: Organic Medium Roast
Review: ong>An easy-going breakfast cup: sweet, gentle, cocoa-toned, ingratiating.

Name: Barista Brava Sumatra
Review: ong>A classic crisply earthy Sumatra at an impressive price.

Name: La Bella Vita Espresso Blend
Review: ong>A complex, powerful straight shot and a superb contributor to long milk drinks.

Name: 100% Pure Jamaican Blue Mountain Coffee
Review: ong>Those who prefer luxury upholstering on their comfortable armchairs.
Coffee Origin: Blue Mountain growing region, eastern Jamaica.

Name: La Minita Costa Rica
Review: ong>A discreetly lavish coffee, understated yet opulent.
Coffee Origin: Tarrazu growing region, central Costa Rica.

Name: Orange Bourbon El Salvador
Review: ong>Lovers of delicately tart, refined and barely sweet desserts.

Name: Rwanda Bufcafe
Review: ong>A balanced, versatile cup, quietly acidy but sweetly smooth, and an excellent candidate for those interested in sampling an origin that is emerging as a distinctive addition to the great East African coffee repertoire.

Name: El Salvador La Montana, Cup of Excellence #1
Review: ong>Those who appreciate beauty but avoid drama.

Name: Panama Elida Estate, Best of Panama #3
Review: ong>Those who enjoy rich but simple beverages.

Name: Kopi Luwak Robusta Dark Roast
Review: ong>Curiosity seekers with money and a good home espresso machine.

Name: Kopi Luwak Arabica Dark Roast
Review: ong>A hearty cup for big spenders.

Name: Kopi Luwak Arabica Medium Roast
Review: ong>Hard to say how much the costly luwak contribution adds to a cup that is different from the typical Sumatra but not startlingly so.

Name: Aged Sumatra
Review: ong>Islay whisky drinkers and others who value rugged wildness over elegance in their beverages.

Name: India Monsooned Malabar
Review: ong>A coffee adventurer's cup.

Name: Kopi Luwak Arabica, Medium Roast
Review: ong>Experimentalists with spare cash, obviously. Judging by our sampling of various versions of kopi luwak available retail in late 2007, the cup character of these coffees varies, perhaps by tree and by luwak, but most do express an interesting and unusual sensory profile, however the details of that profile may vary.

Name: Kopi Luwak Arabica, Bold Roast
Review: ong>Experimentalists with spare cash. Something was going on in the flavor of this particular sample that was quite unique and may (or may not) reflect the peculiar and intimate nature of the processing method.

Name: Aged Sumatra
Review: ong>Port drinkers or anyone who enjoys roundly sweet, fruity beverages tempered by aromatic wood or earth tones.

Name: India Monsooned Malabar
Review: ong>How about metrosexuals: An exceptionally elegant version of the often dauntingly rugged and macho monsooned cup.

Name: 6 Tigers Aged Sumatra
Review: ong>Should please those who enjoy sweet-toned but still pungent beverages like sherry-style fortified wines or Highland single-malt whiskies.

Name: Italian Passion Espresso
Review: ong>Versatile blend with little sharpness but good weight, presence, and fruity depth.

Name: Chopin M?lange Espresso
Review: ong>Fine choice for cappuccino purists.

Name: Arabica Excellence
Review: ong>This gently acidy espresso with its tart fruitiness is a bit sharp as a straight shot but blooms with lovely delicacy in short milk drinks like cappuccino.

Name: Kenya Kigutha
Review: ong>A pure but complex and extravagant cup.

Name: Puro de Puerto Rico, Light Roast
Review: ong>Those who prefer spring mornings to summer afternoons.

Name: Kenya AA Lenana
Review: ong>Those who appreciate shimmers of brightness and crisply elegant dry fruit in a dark-roast presentation.

Name: Sumatra Arabica Lake Tawar
Review: ong>Preserves impressive Sumatra character in a very dark-roasted presentation.
Coffee Origin: Lake Tawar basin, Aceh Province, northern Sumatra, Indonesia

Name: Rwandan Goshonga Reserve
Review: ong>Those who enjoy sweetness and subtly in a dark-roasted coffee.

Name: Melange Francais
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the lean but invigorating intensity of ultra-dark-roasted coffees.

Name: Hacienda La Esmeralda Diamond Mountain
Review: ong>A subtly complex dark roast.

Name: Hacienda La Esmeralda
Review: ong>Those who can afford one of the world's finest and most distinctive coffees.

Name: Kenya AA Mathareini
Review: ong>Austerely classic hedonists.

Name: Espresso Organico
Review: ong>Powerful but elegant in long milk drinks.

Name: El Salvador Cerreo Las Ranas
Review: ong>Those who enjoy medium-roasted ?breakfast? coffees with low acidity and high sweetness.

Name: Yemen Mocha
Review: ong>Those who prefer the interesting to the beautiful.
Coffee Origin: Central north Yemen, probably near Sana'a.

Name: Organic Ethiopian Special Prep
Review: ong>Those who value quiet comfort and a certified organic cup.

Name: Los Lajones Natural Panama
Review: ong>Should resonate well with the cigars and brandy set.

Name: Ethiopia Aricha Seven
Review: ong>A quiet version of berries, chocolate and wine, perhaps for those who find extravagance wearing yet purity boring.
Coffee Origin: Yirgacheffe growing region, Sidamo Province, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Ethiopian Yirgacheffe Hama
Review: ong>A hint of roast taste, full body and a salty-sweet nuance in the fruit make this an interesting choice for those who avoid assertively acidy or floridly fruity coffees.
Coffee Origin: Yirgacheffe growing region, Sidamo Province, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Ethiopian Worka
Review: ong>Lovers of fruity, light, yet pungent beverages: certain grappas and younger tequilas and cachacas (a Brazilian distiled alcoholic beverage made from sugar cane juice).
Coffee Origin: Yirgacheffe growing region, Sidamo Province, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Biloya Selection One Ethiopia
Review: ong>A quiet cup, exotic but comfortable.
Coffee Origin: Yirgacheffe growing region, Sidamo Province, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Aricha Selection #7
Review: ong>Lovers of the juicy opulence and pungent bite of a ripe mango.
Coffee Origin: Yirgacheffe growing region, Sidamo Province, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Ethiopia Beloya Selection One
Review: ong>For Miguel, "those who prefer restrained refinement to hedonistic excess."
Coffee Origin: Yirgacheffe growing region, Sidamo Province, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Ethiopian Aricha Seven
Review: ong>Lovers of the more opulent style of aged tequilas.
Coffee Origin: Yirgacheffe growing region, Sidamo Province, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Arena Selection One Yirgacheffe Ethiopia
Review: ong>A bright, authoritatively dry version of the great Ethiopia natural profile.

Name: Ethiopian Aricha Selection 7
Review: ong>A fine introduction to the deep, lushly fruity Ethiopia dry-processed cup.
Coffee Origin: Yirgacheffe growing region, Sidamo Province, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Honduras El Filo Cup of Excellence
Review: ong>Nostalgics and revivalists. A brightly sweet, old-fashioned American breakfast cup, simple but complete.

Name: Sumatra Mandheling Decaf
Review: ong>I can't imagine a much better traditional Sumatra for caffeine-avoiders who admire the fruity earthiness of this classic coffee type.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing district of the Lake Toba region, North Sumatra Province, Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Sumatra Mandheling Aged 2002
Review: ong>Lovers of certain softly complex but authoritative beverages that combine restrained sweetness, pungency, fruit and earth notes - good Highland single-malt whiskies, for example.

Name: Kenyan Highland Cooperatives
Review: ong>A coffee as extravagant as it is elegant.

Name: Sumatra Lake Tawar
Review: ong>Lovers of intense, sweetly dry, floral white wines; Gew?rztraminer.

Name: Kenya Nyeri AA Tambaya Auction Lot

Name: Sumatran Lake Tawar
Review: ong>Lovers of gingerbreads and rich fruit breads.

Name: Jamaica Blue Mountain
Review: ong>Unusual Blue Mountain, with nut, wood, earth and smoke notes that suggest a Highland malt whisky.

Review: ong>A deep, discreetly roast-rounded coffee with great versatility.

Name: Best of Panama #3 Elida Estate
Review: ong>Those who prefer quiet pleasures.

Name: El Salvador La Montana COE #1
Review: ong>Port drinkers; lovers of sweet but pungent fruit tarts and pastries.

Name: Nicaragua Cup of Excellence Organic

Name: COE Guatemala Lot #2 San Jose Ocana
Review: ong>The perfectly poised roast, just on the cusp between medium and medium-dark, rounds and enriches the aromatics of this delicate coffee without suppressing them.

Name: San Jose Ocana Guatemala COE #2
Review: ong>Those looking for spring in the fall.

Name: El Salvador La Montana
Review: ong>Complex classicists.

Name: Esmeralda Especial Best of Panama
Review: ong>An extravagant coffee, both for the senses and the pocketbook.

Name: Fair Trade Organic House Blend (Wisconsin Union Blend)

Review: ong>Quiet romantics.

Name: Ethiopian Shanta Golba Natural Sidamo
Review: ong>Those who enjoy beverages that walk a complex line between the sweet and the savory; peaty Scotch whiskies and the more pungent tequilas for example.

Review: ong>Pure-palated social idealists who can tolerate some ambiguity in credentialing.

Review: ong>Social idealists who perceive no contradiction between the pure and the voluptuous.

Name: Kenya Karogoto
Review: ong>A classicist's cup, forcefully acidy but gracefully sweet and nuanced.

Name: Espresso Originale
Review: ong>A versatile espresso: lively and powerfully resonant as a straight shot and richly chocolaty in milk.

Name: Brazil Daterra South Italian Style Espresso
Review: ong>An aromatic, versatile espresso for straight shots and short milk drinks.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Wondo
Review: ong>Lovers of the classic Yirgacheffe profile, an always amazing contrast of dizzily fragrant top notes and pungent heart.

Name: Kenya AA Wagamuga Auction Lot
Review: ong>A coffee as extravagant as it is classic.

Name: Panama Esmeralda Especial
Review: ong>A coffee both breathtakingly pure and intriguingly complex.

Name: Panama Hacienda La Esmeralda Gesha
Review: ong>For aficionados, think Yirgacheffe with more flowers and chocolate and less menthol. For those who secretly think all coffees taste the same, try this one.

Name: Costa Rica La Magnolia Tres Rios
Review: ong>Those who enjoy delicate, floral-toned white table wines.

Review: ong>A coffee considerably more Kona (sweet, balanced, softly but vibrantly acidy) than most Konas.

Review: ong>Lovers and potential lovers of the new pulped natural Brazil profile: soft, sweet, honeyish, gently pungent.

Name: Latin BreeZe
Review: ong>A good choice for lovers of the gentler, more moderate style of dark roast.

Name: El Salvador Santa Barbara Estate Organic
Review: ong>More substance than aromatic flash. Try it with milk.

Name: Sumatra (Beveo)
Review: ong>Those who value the convenience of prepared-on-demand concentrate coffee and a subdued, caramelly version of the traditional pungently fruity Sumatra cup.

Name: Amalfi Dark Roast
Review: ong>Almost any darker roasted American espresso is superior to this uncharacteristically dark-roasted and uncharacteristically thin, salty and scorched-tasting Italian effort. Might be better if it were fresher.
Roaster Location: Roasted in Italy; distributed from Louisville, Colorado

Name: Espresso
Review: ong>I suppose those multitudes that drink it every day. Stranded aficionados could do worse.

Name: Selection A Light Roast
Review: ong>A delicate espresso that may show better when fresher.

Name: SuperCrema
Review: ong>Should make an elegant cappuccino.

Name: Gold Espresso
Review: ong>Sweet, simple but roundly balanced straight-shot espresso.

Name: Black Cat Espresso
Review: ong>A versatile espresso for American taste; probably shows best in a short cappuccino.

Name: Extra Mild
Review: ong>A good version of a mild, cleanly robusta-dominated espresso, all fat and depth but with little going on at the top of the profile.

Name: Garuda Blend
Review: ong>A smooth, sweet dark-roast espresso: pungent but complex, without bitterness and with little astringency.

Name: Espresso Coffee
Review: ong>Brand snobs and straight-shot and short-milk drinkers who value subtlety more than power and body. One thing is sure: This is not a blend for drinkers of big, sloppy American-style caffe lattes.

Name: Crema d’Oro
Review: ong>An outstanding blend for cappuccino and caffe latte.

Name: Premium Bar Blend
Review: ong>A versatile espresso, pungent but sweet, particularly attractive in milk.

Name: Massimo

Name: Golden Sumatra
Review: ong>This rather delicate Sumatra makes a pleasingly sweet, light-footed dark roast.

Name: Ethiopia Biloya Special
Review: ong>Lovers of big, complexly fruity red table wines.

Name: Simply Smooth
Review: ong>Those supermarket shoppers too impatient or too budget-strained to shop for a better-tasting stomach-friendly option.

Name: Regular Gourmet Low Acid Coffee
Review: ong>Little acidity but little flavor either. Presumably, it does have the caffeine.

Name: House Blend
Review: ong>This coffee displays low acidity by the simple measure of pH, so for those acidity avoiders who enjoy a gently roasty coffee without much more going on, this may make a good choice.

Name: Idee Special Stomach Friendly Coffee
Review: ong>Give it a try if you like a delicate cup and your stomach struggles with normal coffee.

Name: Sumatra Mandheling
Review: ong>An impressive dark-roasted cup, simple but intense, with little bitterness or astringency and low acidity.
Coffee Origin: Mandheling growing region, northern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Brazil Fazenda Boa Sorte Natural Catuai
Review: ong>The simple, round, low-acid structure with chocolate and walnut tones make this a classic Brazil, a likely candidate for acidity avoiders.
Coffee Origin: Sul de Minas growing region, southern Minas Gerais State, Brazil.

Name: Sumatra Blue Batak
Review: ong>A balanced, elegant variation on the Sumatra cup: Low acidity, big, smooth body, and some juicy citrus notes could make this a good choice for acidity avoiders when brewed in a paper filter.
